ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PRIMARY SCHOOL PRINCIPALS
(Demotion to teachers)


    1. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Education how many primary school principals were demoted to be ordinary teachers in January and February, 1979, before he took over the Ministry, and what is the reason or justification for their demotion.

Column: 560



     The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Sir, nine primary school principals were demoted. This arose out of the 1977 promotion exercise. All principals were interviewed by the Public Service Commission. They were assessed for their fitness to be confirmed as principals. Those considered unfit returned to teaching, where replacements were found.

    The reasons for the Public Service Commission's decision varied from case to case. In addition to assessment at these interviews, staff confidential reports were taken into account. Some principals were found to be lacking in leadership, being too soft on teachers or being unable to motivate them to good performance. Others did not have sufficient professional competence. Others seemed rigid and unwilling to consider different points of view. One was under disciplinary investigation for alleged financial malpractice. Another asked to be demoted.

    The total number of primary school principals covered by this exercise was just over 300. The figure of nine does not show that the Public Service Commission has set up unreasonably stringent standards. Quite the contrary, I would have thought.

     Mr Ho See Beng (Khe Bong): Sir, why did it take so long a time, almost more than two years from 1977 to 1979, for the Ministry of Education to discover that these primary school principals were not efficient, apart from one or two cases; and have they been given a warning prior to their demotion?

     Dr Goh Keng Swee: The delay was due to the fact that although the promotion exercise took place in 1977, the formal appointments were not due to be made until 1978. In fact, there was a delay of just under one year.

    As for warnings, no warning was given because this was the first time, I believe, that the post of principal in schools was considered a promotion post. Previously the

Column: 561

post of principal was not a promotion post, and there had been instances where the principals would be junior to some of the teachers because the teachers did not like to be principals. When it was decided that the post of principal would be a promotion post and would carry allowances, then the exercise had to be carried out.

WORK PERMITS
(Complaint of unfair treatment)


    2. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Labour whether he is aware of the allegation that multinational companies have no difficulty in obtaining work permits by the hundreds for their workers while small local companies find it very difficult to get even one; and whether his Ministry will conduct investigations into the bona fide of the alleged complaint, and, if it is established, whether he will take steps to correct this unfair treatment against our own citizens.

     The Minister of State for Labour (Mr Sia Kah Hui) (for the Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Ministry of Labour does not discriminate between multinational companies and local companies in the issue of work permits. The issue of work permits is also not dependent on the size of the companies. Rather, it is based on the qualifications of the applicants.

    The Ministry recently introduced a Work Permit Scheme for Foreign Workers. This scheme allows manufacturing companies to recruit workers from neighbouring countries on a block basis. Again, the scheme does not make distinction between local or foreign manufacturing companies. Any manufacturing company which is facing difficulties in recruiting large numbers of workers and has the capacity to recruit foreign labour and to provide them with proper accommodation and repatriate them upon expiry of their contracts will be given approval to recruit foreign workers under the scheme.

Column: 562



     Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, since the Minister of State denied that there was discrimination, I wonder whether he is able to produce the number of work permits issued to multinational companies in the last six months, and compare it with the number issued to small local companies for the corresponding period? What is the difference?

     Mr Sia Kah Hui: Sir, of course, I cannot produce the figures. But bearing in mind the number of small local companies, if I produce the figures, he will see a great difference because the multinational companies employ a large number of workers while, as the hon. Member has said, the figure for the small local companies would obviously be very small. So what is the purpose of the comparison?

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Sir could not the Minister of State produce figures to show the proportion of acceptance to rejection of applicants for work permits for multinational companies, against those for the local companies?

     Mr Sia Kah Hui: Sir, obviously I cannot give them right now. If the Member were to file another question, the figures can be supplied.

WIDENING OF LORONG CHUAN


    3. Dr Lau Teik Soon asked the Minister for National Development if his Ministry will expedite the implementation of the plan to widen Lorong Chuan in view of the heavy traffic and frequent congestion along the road from Yio Chu Kang Road to Braddell Road.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Mr Speaker, Sir, in reply to a question raised by the hon. Member for Serangoon Gardens in January 1978, it was explained that there were no proposals to widen Lorong Chuan. The construction of two new roads in the vicinity, namely, the North-South Arterial Road between Thomson Road and Avenue 1, Ang Mo Kio, and the extension of Avenue 1, Ang Mo Kio, from Lorong Chuan to Boundary

Column: 563

Road would relieve the peak hour traffic congestion along Lorong Chuan. These roads are scheduled for completion by December 1979 and October 1980 respectively.

     Dr Lau Teik Soon (Serangoon Gardens): Sir, in view of what the Minister has just said, would he consider two proposals to alleviate the present problem of traffic congestion along Lorong Chuan: (a) to widen the stretch of road along Lorong Chuan, which has only one lane traffic; and (b) to install a traffic light system at the junction of Lorong Chuan and Serangoon Garden Way.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, to question (a), the answer is yes. The Public Works Department is considering the widening of Lorong Chuan, the stretch of one-lane traffic at the junction of Lorong Chuan and Braddell Road. And to question (b) on the installation of a traffic light at the junction of Lorong Chuan and Serangoon Garden Way, it is not practicable because Serangoon Garden Way is only a two-lane carriageway, that means one lane in either direction. If a traffic light is to be installed there, then Serangoon Garden Way will have to be widened to a four-lane carriageway, that means two lanes in either direction, otherwise the traffic light will not function effectively. Installation of a traffic light will involve the acquisition of properties, sometimes taking away the front gardens of residences for the widening of the road. We consider that to be undesirable. It would be better to wait for the new roads to be completed than taking away the front gardens of residences in that area.

Column: 563

HOUSING BOARD SHOP PREMISES
(Rent increase on changes in tenancy)


    4. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for National Development whether there is a limit to the increase in rent of Housing and Development Board shophouses when tenants of such premises are involved in the change of ownership of business and names of tenants.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, shopkeepers' requests for change of trades, inclusion or change of partners, are usually

Column: 564

approved subject to increase in rentals to prevailing market rates for that area. However, total assignment of the premises will not be allowed. In this case, the registered tenants will have to terminate the tenancy and return the shops to the Housing Board.

     Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, does the Minister not think that the increase in rentals to prevailing market rates or to neighbourhood rates obtainable could do an injustice to the tenants, because no two situations are absolutely identical, because one location may be better than the other?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, I agree with the hon. Member that no two situations are identical. However, the assessment of rentals for shops is usually based on the prevailing rates in the surrounding area. If, for example, in a particular neighbourhood the tender for rentals for a provision shop is $800, then we look at it this way. If the particular shop premises that we are considering raising the rental is less favourably located, then the rental will be less than $800. But if that particular shop is better located, then the rental will be higher than $800.

    I might add that the reason for the reassessment of the rental is this. The Housing Board policy on tendering out shops is to base the rental on the highest tender for that particular trade. It is not the highest tender for the shop. Let us say in the Neighbourhood centre we have a number of shops for rent. We usually try to provide the widest range of services possible so that the residents will have a barber shop to go to for a haircut, a bank to bank in their money, and perhaps a pet shop to purchase their birds. So for a shop to sell four digit lottery, the tenant like the Turf Club usually pays the highest rent. For a bird shop, the tenant pays a low rent because he cannot afford to pay a high rent. So if the HDB rents out a shop to the Turf Club, the Club pays a high rent. And if the HDB rents out a shop to a barber, the rent is low. That is the reason why we cannot allow a barber shop to change its trade to, say, a bank or a finance company because that would mean a great difference in the rental. If it wants t

Column: 565

change its trade to a bank, then it will have to pay a higher rental. That is the reason why, when a shopowner requests a change of trade, an upward adjustment of the rental is involved.

    Even though the Housing Board premises are not rent-controlled premises, we do not adjust the rental upwards if the market rental has been increased in that area. But if a shopkeeper wants to assign the shop to other people and thereby collect tea money, it will not be allowed by the Housing Board. That is the reason why we find that the shopkeeper usually takes in new partners first and, after a while, transfers the name of the shop to his new partners. This is, in fact, a roundabout way of trying to assign his shop. In such a case the Housing Board will say, "It is not allowed. If you want to assign the shop to your new partner which you have taken in, then you have to surrender your premises back to the Housing Board.because you will not be allowed to take the tea money."

     Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, based on the Minister's own argument, would he agree that under the circumstances the HDB can overcharge or undercharge the tenant?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, theoretically yes. But, in practice, as I explained earlier, it is not done usually.

     Mr Ho See Beng: Then why is it necessary for the HDB to charge $500 as transfer fee for administrative work?

     An hon. Member: Tea money!

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, this is administrative charges. I read in the newspapers today that fees up to $30,000 are being charged. Generally there is no complaint about this charge of $500.

     Mr Ho See Beng: Is this transfer fee applicable to big and small businesses having their premises in Housing Board estates?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Yes.

     Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, I would like to ask the Minister this. Recently, Singapore

Column: 566

Finance was taken over by Hong Leong. Is he aware that there was a transfer fee?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, when the tenancy is in the name of a company and there is no change of name, then there is no transfer of tenancy. For example, if Singapore Finance has a branch in Toa Payoh and the take-over company continues to use the name of Singapore Finance for that shop premises, then there is no transfer of tenancy at all. But if Hong Leong wants to change the name of that shop to "Hong Leong Finance Company", then of course the HDB will adjust the rental for that premises.

ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [5th March, 1979]

    "That Parliament approves the financial policy of the Government for the financial year 1st April, 1979 to 31st March, 1980.". - [Senior Minister of State for Finance].

    Question again proposed.
2.50 p.m.

     Mr Ho See Beng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I must congratulate the Minister for Finance and the Senior Minister of State for Finance for a painless budget which, instead of following the traditional pattern of introducing new

Column: 567

taxes, has granted several concessions - concessions which are apparently possible without upsetting the Government's financial equilibrium.

    It is obvious that these concessions, involving loss of revenue, have been made possible only because of the tough and pragmatic measures taken by our Government during the past few years to meet the consequences of crises in the world economy, the changing patterns of international trade and repercussions of economic nationalism.

    It is gratifying to note, however, that although there was a 4.5% inflation in 1978, our economy grew by 8.6%. In terms of international economic competitiveness, even though the economic growths of Hong Kong, South Korea and Taiwan were better than that of Singapore, their inflation rates were higher, being 5.7%, 16.4% and 5.7% respectively.

    In paying tribute to the Government for its success in keeping our rate of inflation below the figure of our economic growth, I am constrained to ask whether the Government is appreciative of the contribution of Labour in keeping this figure so low. I am prompted to ask this question because there are many factors which determine the rate of inflation. The role of labour should not be overlooked or disregarded. I am therefore astonished to find that the Minister's statement did not include a positive reference to the contribution made by the trade unions and workers of Singapore towards assisting the Government to maintain high economic growth, with a low inflation rate.

    It is often bemoaned that the young workers of today take full employment and affluence for granted, as their birth right; but it seems to me that the Government is similarly guilty of such an attitude. Those of us who were in the Labour movement in the 1950s know the difficulties that confronted workers in those days. The contribution of workers to Singapore's development and economy should not be forgotten.

    Briefly, in the 50's the workers sacrificed their personal freedom and employment in

Column: 568

their struggle for independence, arm-in-arm with the nationalists who were seeking independence for Singapore. In the early 60's, the workers, grouped under the banner of the NTUC, helped the Government to defeat the communists in the trade union movement and ousted the stooges in the trade union movement who, acting on instructions of their principals in other countries, sought to disrupt Singapore's economy and overthrow the Government by violence. In the 70's organised labour began to play an important role as partners in economic development by ensuring social, economic and political stability so that our economy could grow and yet keeping it internationally competitive.

    The House will recall that in 1968 when Singapore faced serious economic problems as a consequence of British withdrawal, the Government introduced the restrictive Employment Act which would in ordinary circumstances have created an uproar in any democratic country. But the workers of Singapore, having considered the circumstances and the grave problems facing our Republic, subordinated their own interests to the overall national interest by accepting many restrictions and impediments for the common good. And it cannot be denied that their responsible attitude has been a major contribution to the investment climate and Singapore's economic growth.

    Having decided to be partners in economic development, the trade unions have resolved their problems by consultation and by exercising great restraint. They have joined in productivity schemes, they have worked hard, and have thus in no small way contributed to our economic growth of 8.6%; they have also contributed in keeping inflation down to 4.8%.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, one has only got to look around to see what chaos trade unions can bring about if they choose to be trenchant, truculent, irresponsible and self-centred. One has only to look at the newspapers every day to see how national economies can be upset and disorganised by trade unions who do not concern themselves with their countries'

Column: 569

state of development and economic progress. Britain, from whence came our basic trade union concepts, was, for example, thrown into utter confusion by a series of strikes which paralysed the country. This pattern of trade union manipulation and irresponsibility has manifested itself in several countries.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I am therefore extremely surprised that the Government has not deemed it necessary to publicly acknowledge the role of our National Trades Union Congress by giving it more tangible recognition in the form of some financial support to the Labour Foundation. When the Labour Foundation Bill was introduced, I was aghast at the statement in the explanatory note in the Bill saying that "the establishment of this Foundation would not involve the Government in any financial commitment". I would have thought that, in recognising the role played by organised labour through the National Trades Union Congress, the Government would be more than happy to make a substantial contribution year by year to show its appreciation of the contribution made by the trade union movement to Singapore's economic growth and lower inflation rate. But what do we observe from the present budget? To quote the words of Mr Harold Wilson, all we hear is "a deafening silence" as regards the role played by labour in support of Singapore's economic and social growth.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, no rational person can deny that for the workers of Singapore, grouped under the banner of the Singapore National Trades Union Congress, the over-riding factor in industrial matters is our national interest.

    Our trade unions and their leaders have made sacrifices and contributions to Singapore's development and it should be apparent to all that Singapore, without our National Trades Union Congress, would be like Rome without the Vatican. Without an organisation like the NTUC and the dedicated persons at the helm, Singapore's economy may well fall apart.

Column: 570



    In the circumstances, Mr Speaker, Sir, may I suggest that Government acknowledges the role of the trade union movement of Singapore and demonstrates this acknowledgement in a tangible way by making a substantial annual grant to the Singapore Labour Foundation which has been set up at the request of the NTUC for the benefit of workers, both unionised and non-unionised.
3.00 p.m.

     Dr Koh Lip Lin (Nee Soon)( In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, firstly, I would like to congratulate the Senior Minister of State for Finance for presenting what has been unanimously accepted as a painless budget. Although the various tax concessions will not benefit every one, all are happy because there are no new tax measures. Last year, we maintained a fairly satisfactory rate of economic growth, together with a low unemployment rate and a small rise in the cost of living index. All these proved our success in 1978 which we hope to repeat this year.

    The 1979 world economic preview is not good. The increased price of oil will cause a rise in the prices of other materials. In addition, the instability in the international scene and the gradual spread of protectionism will prove to be a detriment to our nation's development. However, I believe that in the coming year, local and foreign investments in our country will gradually increase and Singapore will not only develop into a service centre in this area but will also become one of the safest countries to invest in.

    In the Budget statement, I am glad to learn that the Government will encourage industrial research and development (R and D). At present, most of our important industries depend on imported expertise and technical know-how. It is time we promoted and carried out our own industrial research and development, without which our industries will not last nor be able to compete with that of other countries. It is a wise decision to extend to new manufacturing companies the provision to deduct

Column: 571

expenditure incurred on R and D for income tax purposes. Undoubtedly, this will help to attract more investments.

    I am also glad to note that the Ministry of Finance is carrying out a long-term research and development project in conjunction with other departments concerned, such as the Ministry of Science and Technology, the Science Council and SISIR, to promote research and development and to train the personnel required. I hope the staff in our tertiary institutions will be given a chance to participate when this project is implemented. Please do not overlook the manpower resource and potentialities of these people.

    I agree that we should not emphasise on the fundamental researches which only the Great Powers can afford. However, mastering and transmitting of fundamental knowledge in science and technology constitute the basis on which training of personnel in research and development is based. Therefore, our Government should give its fullest support to the future development of our science and technological faculties of our tertiary institutions. From the Budget, we can see that the sum allotted for R and D for the departments mentioned above is far too small. But I hope this is only the beginning, and the Government will in future give greater assistance to industrial research and development.

    Our nation is at present marching towards industrialisation which has brought us, as everybody knows, economic benefit and employment opportunities. However, it has also brought about some undesirable consequences, one of which is pollution. Pollution is inevitable in industrial development. We cannot escape from it. We can only minimise it. The Ministry of the Environment has introduced certain laws and regulations against pollution. Its officials visit the factories regularly to ensure that the regulations are being followed. The Anti-Pollution Unit does check on the extent of pollution in the various districts. However, pollution caused by industrial activities is not easy to control. Sometimes pollution caused

Column: 572

by industries, intentionally or unintentionally, was discovered to be very serious only when it was too late to remedy. This has happened in Japan, the United States and the West European countries. Singapore is a small island. We cannot permit any serious pollution. Recently, a certain pond in Changi was discovered to contain cyanide; and radioactive material was found in a steel mill. Fortunately, no serious damage was caused, but it suffices as a warning to us. The disposal of industrial effluent water and waste gases generally costs money. In order to economise, some manufacturers have found it expedient to let their factories emit large amounts of black smoke or odorous gases during the night or weekends when the officials from the Ministry of the Environment are not around. To the people in Jurong Town, this has become a common occurrence. I hope the Government department concerned would be more stringent in enforcing the law against industrial pollution. However, assistance should be given to the small-scale industries, particularly the indigenous industries, when the department tackles the problem of industrial pollution.

    Now I would like to touch on some problems on education. Right now, bilingualism is one problem that is attracting the greatest concern from the people in Singapore. Over the last few years bilingual education has been vigorously implemented in our schools, but the result has been far from ideal. Hence, the Ministry of Education has made quite a number of adjustments in its education policy and its measures which are aimed at improving the quality of education in our schools. But members of the public are usually not aware of the background to and the objectives of these changes and they are therefore most dissatisfied with the so-called sudden and hasty changes introduced by the Ministry. Both parents and pupils are often bewildered by such sudden changes.

    To the Singaporeans, next to making money, what preoccupies them most is their children's education and their future. Any policy or measure that prejudices their

Column: 573

children's chance of getting into a good school, or getting a good grade in the examination, or getting into a university, is bound to spring a grouse.

    Second language teaching in Singapore has not been very successful. Although we have produced students who have mastered two languages, they are in the minority. The general run of students is deficient in second language. Even undergraduates, who are within the best 5% of our student population in terms of intelligence or scholastic performance, are barely proficient in their first language and sadly deficient in their second language. It is inconceivable that these top 5%, having studied the second language continuously for 12 years, several hours a week, could attain only a low standard. The only conclusion we can arrive at is that something must have gone wrong somewhere in our education process. I do not intend to speculate as to where the flaw lies, whether it be the students, parents, teachers or the Ministry of Education. Nevertheless, the flaw exists and nobody can deny this. It is hoped that the Ministry will as soon as possible try to identify the root cause of the flaw and apply the necessary measures to rectify it.

    While we do not deny the importance of learning and mastering two languages, we should not over-emphasise the acquisition of languages for that is not the main object of education. The main object of education is to bring up young people to become useful citizens. What we need are people with the necessary training and knowledge to maintain the prosperity and progress that we have achieved, a people imbued with a sense of national consciousness, high moral values and a fine cultural tradition. The cultivation of such qualities is more important than the studying of languages. It is hoped that, while reviewing the school curriculum and teaching methods, the Ministry will not lose sight of this objective.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, there is a very apt saying in Chinese which goes: "it takes ten years to

Column: 574

grow a tree, but it takes a hundred years to nurture a man." Education is a matter of vital and lasting importance in nation building. How we educate our next generation will decide whether we prosper or perish in future. The effects of any changes in education policy and system made today will not be seen in the next two or three years. Any improvement can only be felt in the next five or ten years. Similarly, the effects of any wrong measures can be detected only after a period of time. In this case the plan for acquisition showed "lallang land" and therefore it was a very cheap piece of land, so it was red pencilled and marked out for acquisition. Later, they found that there were houses there, and they could not de-gazette it because this would create a precedent and would apply to other places. How could they gazette this? What happened? How do they justify this blunder? I do not know, This is one example.

    Then there was an example of a woman who lost her citizenship - in five minutes - and got it back after three rather naughty letters from me. I am not claiming any credit, but I just want to show an example of the Government machinery which operates with total ignorance of the real life situation of Singapore, our people, our culture. This woman met me and said that she lost her citizenship. I asked her how did she lose it. She said, "i don't know. I was told to go to the Identity Card Office with two photographs. They withdrew my pink identity card and gave me a blue identity card." I wrote to this Office. They replied that the date of birth on her old identity card did not tally with that in the Birth Certificate and she could not therefore prove that it was her Birth Certificate. Subsequent letters of appeal were written and I got the same reply. I sensed that this woman was wronged and so, in one of my meet-the-people sessions, I asked my staff to borrow a Chinese almanac from next door. On going through the almanac, I discovered that the date of birth on her old identity card was exactly the same as that shown in the Birth Certificate but it was based on the Chinese calendar. This is an old practice! So I wrote to the National Registration Office and Citizenship Registry and she got her citizenship back. My next

Column: 629

question is: How many more such cases are there? The point is when we deal with our people, we must understand their cultural background. There should be a checklist so that even a non-Chinese officer who comes across such a case would be able to go through the checklist first before revoking the citizenship. I asked, "How many more such cases are there?" The officer replied, "We don't know, Mr Fong. I really don't know myself." This is one goof. How does one justify this?

    Then there is the Registry of Companies. The Management Services Department moved into the Registry of Companies and recommended that to save costs, the Registry should do away with the telephone operator and that each officer should have a direct line. So if you want to ring the Registry of Companies to speak to an officer on a certain subject, you will just have to ring any of these lines. But the very senior and highly paid "telephone operator" at the other end would say, "Sorry, this matter does not concern me. It is the other officer. Please ring this number. I cannot transfer the call because this is a direct line." For every six telephone calls I make, according to the law of averages there will be five wrong numbers! All this just to save the cost of a telephone operator? Justification of a blunder? They say it is efficiency!

    I remember when I was the Member for Stamford and before my "resettlement", I made a proposal to erect an overhead bridge at the High Street junction, so that traffic could proceed ahead. The only function of the traffic light there was to stop the traffic just to allow the pedestrians to cross the road. I received a reply saying that it could not be done because the site there was encumbered with underground services and they had no money. A few months later I saw construction work going on there. I rang the PWD and asked what was being done in my constituency. They said, "Oh, we are going to construct an overhead bridge." On hearing this, I vigorously opposed the idea. After about ten minutes of discussion, the officer said, "Well, if I am not mistaken, Mr Fong, it

Column: 630

was your proposal that we are now talking about!" I said, "But then you told me the site was encumbered with underground services." He said, "Oh, we have now found out that it was not so." then while they were building the bridge, they issued a statement saying that the PWD was building it, I have nothing against them, Sir. They were doing good work. It is a natural tendency of the so-called experts and professionals that every time a layman, and an MP in particular, proposes an idea, they will not implement it even if they agree to it, because if a layman can provide a solution when the experts cannot, they should not be there any more. This is a typical example of cutting you down first because "we will do it ourselves.."

    This also happened in my proposal for the provision of canteen space in multi-storey buildings. I raised the question with the Ministry of the Environment at a meeting chaired by my colleague, the Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, with the URA representative. Their impression was this: "We build a multi-storey building. To put a canteen inside is un-becoming of a good architect?" The answer was no. It took them three months to reply to the Ministry of the Environment who conveyed their decision to me that it could not be done. A multi-storey building should not provide this kind of service because they expected the clerks and the sales girls to eat at the restaurant in that building? They would probably eat up their salary in three days! But, four months later it was declared as a matter of policy that multi-storey buildings should have canteen space for the staff! So they will slaughter you first, have the idea re-hashed, or re-born, so that it will be one up for that ministry. i am not challenging them for doing good work. Neither do I envy them. What I wish to inform Members is their attitude towards suggestions from Members of Parliament.

    Here is another very interesting case. We know that it is very difficult to get money from the Government. Sir, I claim the credit of getting one dollar from the Government. I was to be blamed, Sir, for delaying payment of my road tax. When I decided to pay, the

Column: 631

tax went up! Rather unhappily, I went there to pay my road tax. The officer said, "Well, you have to pay so much now." Reluctantly, I paid. Six months later I received a letter. The only politeness in that letter was the word "please". It was a cyclostyled letter. That means there were many similar cases. The subject matter read: "Re: your car number .... short payment, $2. Please see the undersigned on receipt of this letter with your registration book ....", and so on. They made a mistake, and I received a cyclostyled letter saying, "Come and see me with your book" So I wrote in, not on Parliament letterhead for fear of being accused of browbeating the civil servants. (The Minister for the Environment here had accused me of trying to be a hero. I will come to that point later.) I inquired from them as to how I had short paid $2. They replied that the tax should be this amount and not that amount and so I had short paid $2. I wrote again saying, "When I approached the officer, I paid the amount as demanded. Therefore, there was no question of a short payment." They replied that there was a change in the tax rate and the officer in charge had miscalculated it, resulting in an under-collection of $2. I contended that "under-collection" is quite different from "short payment". In the case of a short payment the liability was mine. I asked them under which provision of the law that a member of the public has to pay to rectify a mistake of the Government. A reply came promptly, "Please be magnanimous. Pay the $2." We have to pay for our magnanimity! I wrote back saying, "In the spirit of magnanimity I will pay, but only on condition that you promise by return of post that you are prepared to pay for my transport cost to get down to your office, my time taken to attend to this matter and the cost of one registered letter." A reply came back again, "Please pay in order to be magnanimous." Finally, I told them that in the spirit of magnanimity, I would waive all charges except $3 as a token fine for their mistake. As a result, after the deduction of $2 which I owed them, they now owe me $11. I received a reply enclosing a receipt for $2 and $1 cash. That $1 is still in my file. I shall have to frame it up. (i did not indulge in illegal activity

Column: 632

on receipt of the $1, Sir. I was tempted to do so, but as a good Member of Parliament, I did not.) I managed to get $1 out of a Government department. But I lost $19 in the end. I wrote them a letter, this time on my letter-head, saying that I did not do so in the past for the reason which I have stated earlier. Now that commonsense finally prevailed, there was cause for celebration. I did so in the form of a donation of $20 to the ROV Officers' Sports Club. $19 was my own donation and the $1 from the Government department for their penance. It was yet another justification for a mistake! They make a mistake, you pay for it, being a good citizen.

    I can go on, Sir, giving many other examples. But I am afraid you will rule me out of order. We have to confine ourselves to discussion of the general principles of the Budget Statement. The examples which I have quoted do illustrate that at times there are lapses in the Civil Service in implementing Government policies. We spend $603 million on manpower and salaries alone this year.

    I must state here, and I think the Minister for National Development would be pleased to hear it, that I do enjoy extremely good cooperation from the Resettlement Department. These officers were or are - I hope they still are - quite enlightened. But at times they can only be enlightened after I have enlightened them. There was a case of resettlement. A farmer was offered an alternative piece of land. There were two brothers and two pieces of land were offered. The elder brother moved in first. After some months the younger brother bought all the timber, planning to move in on to the new piece of land. But the elder brother said, "Don't, this land is again being acquired." So the younger brother did not move in, but in the end he lost all his claims for the original compensation on the grounds that he had failed to take occupation of the land offered. But the land offered was once again acquired. The matter lasted for six years until I went to the constituency. I charged the Resettlement Department for expropriation and then they agreed in the end to pay what

Column: 633

they call "ex gratia payment". They cannot call it "compensation" because that would mean admitting their mistake. They had to justify their mistake by calling the payment "ex gratia payment". That is one example.

    Another example is that frequently we find that in resettlement cases a family will approach the Resettlement Department saying, "Can I have two units because my son is now married?" The standard reply reads, "When we did the census, there was only one family unit. We cannot now give you another unit." I took the matter up with the Resettlement Department and asked them to produce the law which says that once a family has been censured for resettlement, no member of the family can contract a marriage. I do know, Sir, that in my old constituency some places had been censured for resettlement but no clearance for ten years. We do not expect a young maiden to wait 10 years to get married! Does it mean that if a person gets married, he or she is not entitled to a house? Sir, on that argument the Resettlement Department relented and agreed to offer an additional unit, albeit on a rental basis. At least the family has a place to stay. There were several similar cases. On the same argument each of them obtained an additional unit.

    Fortunately or unfortunately, their brains did not stop working, as far as the resettlement officers are concerned. To my amusement, one day I received a letter from the Department in reply to a similar case of a request for an additional unit. It stated, "We regret to inform you that we are not able to offer you an additional unit on the grounds that your marriage was not consummated." Sir, for 17 years as a Member of Parliament, I have never come across such logic or argument, I replied to the Department and, among other things, I stated, "Since civilization began, a matter such as the consummation of a marriage is not normally done in the presence of a witness." The Housing Board took on the role of the High Court. They almost nullified the marriage. Only the High Court can decide whether or not a marriage

Column: 634

is consummated and only upon a complaint by either of the parties. In this particular case, although there was no complaint, they ruled that the marriage was not consummated! See how do they justify a blunder? The reply to my two-page letter was indeed very short. "Please refer to your letter dated so-and-so. I am pleased to inform you that the couple has now been offered an additional unit."

    As I have said, I can go on giving examples. My intention here is to bring to the attention of the Ministry of Finance, the MSD, and particularly those people who implement policies, of the need to be flexible, humane, and to bear in mind the kind of people they are dealing with. Strict adherence to the rules is good. But they should allow some flexibility. Rules are made to guide the civil servants to work more efficiently and expeditiously. The Instruction Manual runs into three volumes. But they are based on past experiences to help the officers to discharge their duties in the most efficient, expeditious and humane way. But unfortunately, some of them allow themselves to be tied up in knots by the same Instruction Manual which is designed to help them. The examples which I have quoted are not that serious, but if we do not check all these minor lapses here and there, many citizens will be wronged. In the example of the identity card case which I quoted earlier, if that citizen were to approach a Member of Parliament who is not conversant with Chinese culture, she would have been wronged for the rest of her life. For one citizen to be wronged, that is bad enough, Sir. There is no recourse to litigation because if she were to go to court she could not prove that it was her certificate until a little detective work on culture was done by an MP. These lapses should remind us that there should be some check lists in the various Ministries. If they are confronted with a situation there should be a check list with which they can go through the various points before taking the rather unpleasant action, say, revoking the citizenship of a person. It is a serious matter, Sir. Regarding my query on how many more such cases, there was no answer. Since we spend $603 million on manpower and salaries, should there not be a

Column: 635

special unit set up, perhaps under the MSD, to look into lapses like those I have just mentioned? The unit can propose some guidelines as to the degree of flexibility that can be allowed under certain circumstances.

    It is an unpleasant thing to have to resettle people but they generally accept that resettlement is for the benefit of the State. The principle should be that whilst no one should benefit from resettlement, neither should the people suffer as a result of it.

    It is therefore important that this special unit be set up as quickly as possible because as we increase the tempo of development, the officers tend to be more and more indifferent and they follow the book more and more. "After all, I draw a day's pay. I follow the guide book. If certain things cannot be done, they can see their Member of Parliament." A Member of Parliament can only offer to his people his sincerity, his willingness to work hard for his people, but he cannot offer all the solutions, still less provide answers for administrative stupidity. I do not think that is the role of the Member of Parliament. Fortunately, our meet-the-people session is a good bridge between the people and the Government. From our experience, we can gauge the general feelings of the population. But I do not think that is enough, Sir. What should be done is that the various departments should have their own guidelines on certain cases, particularly citizenship. It is a serious matter, and yet these guidelines are absent. They are merely following rules. And if the Minister for Finance can allow a provision in the MSD - first of all, the MSD themselves must be enlightened - and if all the Ministries were to suffer the same fate as the Registry of Companies where all the officers have direct lines, then we have to find another MSD to advise the MSD. It is important, Sir, that these lapses here and there should be checked. And it is all these grievances that sway the general mood of the people.

    On that note and with the hope in mind that the Senior Minister of State will respond to this suggestion to check the various lapses in the Ministry, I rather reluctantly associate myself in supporting the financial statement.

     Mr Tan Soo Khoon (Alexandra): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, last December the world was shocked when the 13-nation OPEC cartel announced a general increase of 14.5% in the price of oil for 1979. OPEC tried to cushion the shock by spreading the increases over four stages throughout the year. Then events moved fast. A political crisis in Iran erupted. In a few short months of incessant political turmoil, export of oil from Iran plunged from 5.5 million barrels a day to nothing. Even if the Iranians should now resume exports, the future is bleak. Iranian oil will cost an incredible US$20 per barrel. But what is made worse is that other countries will now follow Iran's example, and there is a possibility of OPEC announcing another increase beyond the 14.5% it has already set for this year. It is not an un-imaginable situation as oil is always in short supply and many developed countries which need oil badly are prepared to pay any price for oil. The so-called "spot market" has also contributed to the spiralling price of oil. With spot prices reaching dazzling heights of US$30 per barrel as a result of speculation by middlemen, the temptation is there for OPEC countries to join the rampage. The sky appears to be the limit for the price of oil. This will have serious effects on the world economy.

    Inflation is bound to take its toll on developed as well as developing countries. More US dollars will flow into oil producing countries adding to the vast billions already accumulated by these countries since the last oil crisis. This means a further weakening of the value of the US dollar against other major currencies and will in turn undermine the international monetary system.

    Very evidently the world is in a critical stage. It is on the brink of falling headlong into its second economic crisis in five years. The important thing to us is what we as Singaporeans, subject to the effects of events happening elsewhere and which are beyond our control, can do to brace ourselves for

Column: 637

what the Senior Minister of State for Finance has said would be an "uncertain and wintry economic climate."

    We have to take positive steps to reduce our consumption of energy. A few days ago when the Senior Minister of State for Finance performed on television, he warned of the possibility of higher prices for energy because of the oil shortage and price hike. No rightminded Singaporean will chide him for that. On the contrary, we should be grateful for his warning, and begin to take steps to conserve energy. It was perhaps unfortunate that after the first energy crisis of 1973/74 when Singaporeans were first made conscious of the need to conserve energy, no further serious efforts were made to sustain the drive to reduce consumption. For Singaporeans, the first energy crisis seemed to have gone as fast as it came as few realized that the luxury of switching on electricity at the touch of the fingertips is a luxury that has become too precious to waste. Even as OPEC was announcing their price increase last December, Orchard Road was buried in an orgy of dazzling lights as hotels competed with one another to see which had more and brighter lights during Christmas - indeed a very appalling situation if you consider the amount of precious electricity that must have been wasted during that period.

The latter is something we rather not have if it can be avoided, and avoid it we can by painstakingly taking every conceivable measure to save on the use of energy. I can think of a few examples, e.g. economising on the use of air-conditioning in buildings (this Chamber included), switching off the lights and air-conditioning during lunch breaks, bathing in cold water instead of heating it, cutting down on unnecessary journeys by car thereby saving on petrol, restricting the use of illuminated advertising signboards. Sir, the examples I have given may sound petty but a little bit

Column: 638

saved here and a little bit saved there all adds up to a pretty big sum. There are indeed numerous ways we can save energy if we stretch our imagination a bit further but every individual has to play his part. The Government on its part must in no way relent on its efforts to drive home the message and if necessary take measures against those who persist in flouting the national effort towards saving energy.

    Sir, I support the Motion standing in the name of the Senior Minister of State for Finance.

     The Senior Minister of State for Finance (Mr Goh Chok Tong): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, had the Budget which I described as painless received nothing but pleasurable tributes, I would have been sorely disappointed: first, at the lack of mental vigour and the inquiring spirit of the MPs and, secondly, I would have considered the Budget to be somewhat of a failure, that is, if I had not received any reservation or comments on the Budget.

The Budget has therefore to be objective and to be aware of imminent difficulties in the world economy. Thus, even though the Budget is painless, it is not aimed at gaining complete popularity. It is not possible. No Finance Minister, and certainly not the Finance Minister in Singapore, is a Santa Claus distributing goodies to each and everyone in the country. What we can do is wherever possible to take a little sometimes and give a little wherever we can.     Before I come to the specific points raised by several Members of the House, I would like to dispose of the criticism that a television forum was held even before the representatives of the people had a chance to debate the Budget. I make no apologies for the forum. I regard the Budget as a document of national interest, and it is important that as many people as possible are given a chance to debate the budget as soon as the Budget statement is made. The Finance Ministry or the Finance Minister, or I myself who had a hand in the Budget statement this year, not only have to face the representatives of the people, i.e. the Members of Parliament, but also the people of Singapore. The television forum is only one additional step taken by me to explain through the mass media to the people through a panel of experts certain logic or rationale behind the Budget.

    I recognise the problem, however, that the Budget could forestall discussion by Members of Parliament but I have faith in the Members of Parliament that the forum would not deprive them of issues to raise just as they have done today despite the forum. It is a question of timing. It is not possible to have the television forum after the Budget debate because the Budget statement would have undergone thorough examination after a session in this House. In fact, even among the members themselves, one member felt that the hour-long discussion was not long enough. I hope he did not mention this with tongue-in-cheek. But the fact is true that an hour-long discussion would not be sufficient to pre-empt issues that would be raised by Members of the House. So I trust Members of the House understand the logic behind the television forum. I trust that the television forum, while discussing various issues of importance to the people of Singapore, has not robbed any Member of the House of the capacity to debate, to make reservations, or to criticise the Ministry.

    I would like to divide my reply into two sections, one dealing with concessions and the other on general economic matters.

    On concessions, reservation was expressed by several Members of the House

Column: 641

on the budget not taking into adequate consideration the lower income workers who did not enjoy the benefit of an increase in the exemption limit for CPF contributions, I also had to sit through some embarrassing moments listening to my own arguments when I was on the other side of the House arguing for a case for personal and earned income reliefs to be upped. I would like to explain that I was convinced by the Minister for Finance as to the logic for not increasing the personal and earned income reliefs and I hope, in the course of the next few minutes, to be able to convince them so that this issue would not be raised again and again.

It is not possible to give an exact figure because there will be newcomers to the tax range and we cannot accurately pinpoint how many newcomers will get into the tax bracket. Also, if we were to increase the personal relief by $1,000 everyone will benefit but not by the same absolute amount. Those in the lower income group, whom Members of Parliament feel passionately for, will benefit by $50 because their tax rate is 5%. But those in the higher income group who have a marginal tax rate of 40% would benefit by $400. The measure will therefore appear to be regressive.

There was, however, again criticism of the sin of omission on the part of the Finance Ministry, i.e. those pensioners who are not paying tax do not enjoy this particular concession, and arguments have been advanced that they are, in fact, the people who should also enjoy similar recognition from the Government for their hard work in the past. The answer to that is that if they do not pay tax, it is not possible to exempt them from paying tax. Our first step in granting some tangible recognition to those who have served is not to take away from them. At a later stage perhaps, when

Column: 642

we can afford it, we could consider a further step, i.e. giving something to those who deserve it. This was done in 1974 when the new Singapore allowance was introduced for pensioners with a monthly pension of less than $650. They were given an ex gratia payment, having taken into account the steep rise in the cost of living following the oil crisis. I can assure Members of the House that my Ministry monitors the plight of these pensioners, and if later events prove that a similar ex gratia payment is necessary, I am sure the Government will not be hard-hearted.

The first point was whether the exemption cannot be extended to more than one house. I think that point can be considered. If we were to exempt, as was intended in my Budget statement, only the first house up to the limit of $200,000 there is a possible interference with ownership pattern. Husbands and wives normally would have joint ownership of a piece of residential property. Some families are fortunate to be able to own two pieces of residential property. If we were to exempt only one house, that is the first house, from the enhanced limit, then for estate planning purposes I could envisage a shift in ownership pattern. If the donor unfortunately dies within five years of the gift and we allow the exemption limit of $200,000 to apply to that piece of property, we are allowing an exemption on a property that does not belong to him. We have also to look at the situation where it is also possible that, through some unfortunate event, the donee may die before the donor, in which case he will be able to claim exemption up to $200,000 on that piece of

Column: 643

property. Thus we have a case where it is possible to have two persons claiming the exemption on the same piece of property.
